Hi Gordon,

> Generally, Heritrix is not yet well-sutted for incremental
> or continuous crawling, which would most benefit from
> modification-date, etag, or content-change analysis.

Wouldn't archive.org benefit from knowing which pages
are unchanged since the last scan and by reducing
the total amount of downloaded pages?

> Kris Sigurï¿½sson's work, the AdaptiveRevisitFrontier (included
> in the standard Heritrix distribution), could be of interest
> here. It revisits sites according to a schedule, and adjusts
> the revisit intervals based on observed change rates of
> resources.

I have looked int the class....

> It doesn't use HEAD or if-modified-since requests, but I
> believe the associated HTTPMidFetchUnchangedFilter will
> consult modification times and etags, when present, to
> make a quick determination that a resource is unchanged.
> If so, the GET will be aborted early (and the scheduling
> adjusted as necessary).

And that's bad, I think, because aboding requests is much
less polite than using if-modified-since. As far as I remember
(loooong time ago, when the discussion started about HTTP/1.1)
it is relative expensive to establish a connection. That was
the reason, why HTTP/1.1 added the keep-alive feature.

OTOH, heritrix seems to delay between contacting a server,
and that might be even more polite. So, maybe heritrix is
not the right framework for my spider, because my spider
would be in general as polite as heritrix unless a user
focuses on a particular site, then it should behave similar
to a web browser (a few connections with keep-alive)...

Michael
